children.text: [Template] How much is Apple worth? Breaking down a DCF model for AAPL.
How much is Apple worth? Breaking down a DCF model for AAPL.
Apple is one of the most valuable companies in the world with a market cap of
Apple is valued or whether its current market price is overvalued or undervalued?
One approach to valuing a company like Apple is to use a discounted cash flow (DCF) model, which takes into account the company's future cash flows to estimate it's current value.

This interactive model breaks down how to build a DCF model for Apple and estimate an intrinsic value per share. Intrinsic value is an estimate of the fair value of a company; not actual market conditions.
. You can duplicate this model to reuse it or modify it and make it your own.

My first step in constructing this DCF model is to estimate Apple's future cash flows. There are many ways to do this, but one approach is to use historical financials to make assumptions about a company's future revenue growth, margins, and capital expenditures.
I am going to look back 5 years for Apple. You may want to look back 10 years to capture a broader cycle.
I am going to make some general assumptions to forecast future free cash.
When looking at key drivers of future free cash such as
and my own assumptions on the market, I am going to assume
growth in Apple's future free cash. That free cash will maintain it's post 2020 levels.
To represent this, I will use an average of Apple's free cash flow and EBITDA from the last two years as the future free cash (FFC) and future EBITDA.
represents the estimated value of a company beyond the final year of the explicit forecast period. It creates a more complete picture of a company's value.
There are different ways to calculate TV. One approach is to assume a company's FCF will grow at a constant rate beyond the projection period —
In this model, TV is the present value of future cash flows in perpetuity. We can estimate TV by using our future free cash flow estimate and dividing by a discount rate. I am going to assume a
close to the ten year treasury rate.

Now, we can discount Apple's projected FCF and TV to their present values using the discount rate. This accounts for the fact that money in the future is worth less than money in the present. We're assuming a
We can calculate this using the
which will calculate the present value of our five year forecasted future cash flows.
We also have to discount Apple's terminal value to present value. TV is in perpetuity beyond our initial forecast. Using the net present value function, it will be 0 for the first 4 years.
Now that we have the present value of FCF and TV, we can compute Apple's enterprise value and market value to get an estimated share value:
In this model, I've made two main assumptions:
A discount rate near the ten year treasury rate:
No growth in Apple's future free cash:
This results in a value per share for Apple of
We can compare this to Apple's actual share value of
to evaluate if Apple is over or undervalued.
